trial_identification.studytitle: Rotation thromboelastometry (ROTEM 'Registered Trademark') in obstetrics: baseline parameters in normal and complicated pregnancies. A prospective observational study on elective Caesarean patients.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: ROTEM ('Registered Trademark') thromboelastometry in elective Caesarean patients: baseline parameters in normal and complicated pregnancies.
trial_identification.trialacronym: RTC (ROTEM Thromboelastometry in elective Caesarean patients)

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Fetal medicine and complications of pregnancy

interventions.interventions: A 3.5mL (or 7mL if complicated/high-risk for correlation with a coagulation profile) blood sample will be taken to process for a ROTEM profile, at the point of IV cannula insertion pre-operatively. No follow-up with the patient required, but medical records will be reviewed as part of data collection regarding birth outcomes (estimated blood loss, neonatal outcomes).
interventions.comparator: Patients in the normal pregnancy group will act as the comparator.

primaryOutcome.outcome: ROTEM profile assessed using whole blood analysis
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the point of IV cannulation pre-operatively

primaryOutcome.outcome: Outcome of delivery (whether there were any complications in relation to the mother or baby) will be assessed by review of medical records.
Estimated blood loss by review of medical records

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Analysis of changesin coagulation as assessed by ROTEM seen in patients with pregnancy complications and coagulopathies
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: ROTEM will be performed pre-induction of anaesthesia for Caesarean section.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Pregnant and of greater than 30 weeks gestation. Booked for an elective Caesarean section.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Severe cognitive impairment, severe mental illness, moderate to severe intellectual disability

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Statistical advice has been provided by the Statistics Department of the Queensland Institute of Medical Research. The proposed study period will be 12 months and based on estimates, there will be approximately 100 patients potentially included in the study, at which point we will review our data to assess the need for further extension of this study. Demographic and baseline data will be presented as frequencies/percent for categorical data or means/standard deviations for continuous data. Continuous data will be analysed using analysis of variance (ANOVA), and the chi square test will be applied to categorical data. It is difficult in this setting with the aim of deriving normal baseline values for ROTEM and thus formal power calculations cannot be applied. The statistical advice given was to recruit as many patients as possible over a defined study period.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: The Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital Butterfield St, Herston QLD 4029

fundingsource.fundingaddress: The University of Queensland School of Medicine, St Lucia, QLD 4067

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Recruitment of parturients will occur at the Royal Brisbane and Womens Hospital (RBWH). There is increasing use of ROTEM(TM) for point-of-care coagulation monitoring in patients with massive haemorrhage, but there still remains limited data on reference ranges in normal pregnancies and subsequently limited understanding of the effects of complicated pregnancies on ROTEM(TM) interpretation. With the recent implementation of ROTEM(TM) within the RBWH, reference ranges for the obstetric population need to be established to optimise interpretation of derived values.
